Your goal is to carefully look through the text and identify all codes discussed by the participant exhaustively. Each code should be specific and distinct without overlaps.

Write with concise, concrete details and avoid clichs, generalizations.

Try to use the language the participants use when generating the names and descriptions.

Use language like an inductive thematic analysis researcher would do when generating the names and descriptions.

Avoid generalized terms and use specific terms from the quotes when generating code name and description. Be concise.

codes.name: Feeling powerless and overwhelmed by imposed medical interventions and diets
codes.description: Participant describes experiencing deprivation and resentment towards restrictive diets and medical regimes, feeling as though treatment was being imposed rather than collaboratively chosen. quotes: I just sort of felt like it was being done to me...it was perpetuating the trauma in which you felt you were in control of your body and now you're just being told what to do with your body by all these medical professionals.
There can be a sense ... of just being so powerless and so I started realizing with diet and everything else at some point I have to regain my agency and my power and my collaboration in my healing.

codes.name: Experiencing simultaneous relief and devastation upon receiving diagnosis
codes.description: Upon receiving the ME/CFS diagnosis, participant felt initial relief from uncertainty, but also deep devastation and grief when told there was no cure. The diagnosis brought a sense of having a 'death sentence but in a way a life sentence' forced to live with years of illness.
quotes: On the one hand I was relieved to have a diagnosis because I suddenly couldnt go to work...but on the other hand it was really devastating...I remember bawling, you know, being so devastated and really feeling like this was just this death sentence but in a way a life sentence.

codes.name: Struggling with loss of identity and sense of purpose after becoming unwell
codes.description: Participant describes the profound impact of illness causing the loss of a fulfilling career, independence, relationships, and sense of life purpose. quotes: I have no purpose anymore, it was really hard to socialize too...for what I have no purpose anymore.

codes.name: Clinging to hope and a deep intuitive belief in eventual recovery
codes.description: Despite dire prognoses from doctors and years of persistent symptoms, participant maintained a core sense that recovery was possible. quotes: I think though for the most part I was able to kind of keep some just some hope and some optimism although doctors were saying we dont have a cure there was something in me...this isnt my life, this is not how its going to go.

codes.name: Experiencing spontaneous symptom relief following reframing illness as stress-driven

You are a: Experienced researcher.

Research question: Our research question is to understand the experience of patients who have recovered (either partially or fully) from CFS or ME.

You are doing a thematic analysis of transcript data.
You will code a single transcript independently, without using a pre-existing codebook. This is the initial coding stage, where insights will be drawn directly from the text. The results from this stage will determine the subsequent theme generation process.

In this stage, you will generate codes. Codes are the foundational units of inductive thematic analysis, capturing significant concepts and ideas from the transcripts. Each code includes a concise name, a meaningful description, and representative quotes from the transcripts.

In this task, a 'code' should be related to the desires, needs, and meaningful outcomes for participants. Codes pertain to participants. Codes describe the feeling of the participant themselves.

Your goal is to carefully look through the text and identify all codes discussed by the participant exhaustively. Each code should be specific and distinct without overlaps.

Identify all relevant codes in the text, provide a Name for each code in 8 to 15 words in sentence case.

Write with concise, concrete details and avoid clichs, generalizations.

codes.name: Feeling a sense of letting go control of recovery process
codes.description: Participants describe a profound shift where they release strict expectations or pressure to manage every aspect of healing. This involves trusting their bodies and learning to listen internally, rather than striving for a perfect protocol or outcome. This shift is associated with a deep relief and moments of unexpected progress.
quotes: I had to let go and trust my body... not try to force recovery with every supplement.
When I stopped pushing so hard for answers and focused on being gentle with myself, things started changing.
Letting go of control, that was when a big shift happened.

codes.name: Longing to return to normal routines and daily life activities
codes.description: Participants frequently express intense longing for simple, everyday routines like walking, working, or socializing. These desires reflect a yearning for normalcy, independence, and connection with others, and represent significant emotional milestones in their recovery journeys.
quotes: I just wanted to be able to walk my dog like I used to.

It mattered so much to be able to talk to friends again without thinking about symptoms.

codes.name: Living with persistent fear of relapse even during improvement
codes.description: Participants experience a lingering and pervasive fear that their symptoms could return, casting a shadow over improvements. Their anxiety is heightened by past cycles of hope and disappointment, and the unpredictable nature of CFS/ME or Long COVID.
quotes: Every time I felt a little better, I worried, what if it comes back tomorrow?
Even when I was almost normal, the fear didnt go away.
Youre always waiting for the other shoe to drop after each good day.

codes.name: Rediscovering skills in listening and communicating with the body
codes.description: Recovery involves relearning how to interpret physical cues and signals, moving away from ignoring or overriding discomfort. Participants describe a process of tuning into subtle sensations, and becoming attuned to their bodies needs for rest, nourishment, and movement.
quotes: I pay attention to what my body is telling me now, instead of ignoring pain.
Learning to listen for fatigue cues has been crucial.
Im now more aware of what triggers symptoms, and try to respond right away.

codes.name: Experiencing shock and grief over loss of personal identity
codes.description: Many participants express shock and deep grief when reflecting on how illness stripped away core parts of their identity, roles, and relationships. Recovery includes processing this emotional turmoil and coming to terms with changed self-images.
quotes: I didnt recognize myself after months of being so sick.
Theres grieving for the person I used to be, and the things I used to do.
It felt like losing the whole life Id built.

codes.name: Finding hope and motivation from small gains in functioning
codes.description: Participants describe how incremental improvements, such as walking short distances or engaging in minor activities, provide enormous psychological relief and a sense of possibility. These changes are significant sources of hope, often outweighing the negative effects of lingering symptoms.
quotes: Just being able to shower again without help was huge for me.
When I walked to the mailbox by myself, I knew there was progress.
Every little improvement was a big win and made me feel hopeful.

codes.name: Searching for meaning and understanding through illness experience
codes.description: Participants grapple with existential questions, striving to learn lessons or find positive aspects in what feels traumatic. For some, the illness leads to deeper self-reflection, challenging priorities, and shifting perspectives about life, health, and relationships.
quotes: I found myself asking why this happened, and what I was supposed to learn.
There was a need to make sense of it  otherwise, it felt wasted.
Ive changed how I see whats important after this whole experience.

codes.name: Desiring recognition and validation by doctors and the community
codes.description: Participants deeply desire to be believed and respected by medical professionals, friends, and family. This need for validation is shaped by previous experiences of being dismissed, misunderstood, or doubted, and is perceived as a critical aspect of emotional recovery.
quotes: I just needed someone to say, I believe you.
Not being doubted by doctors would have made it easier.
It hurt when people blamed me or didnt understand.

codes.prompt:
You are a: Experienced researcher.

Research question: Our research question is to understand the experience of patients who have recovered (either partially or fully) from CFS or ME.

You are doing a thematic analysis of transcript data.
You will code a single transcript independently, without using a pre-existing codebook. This is the initial coding stage, where insights will be drawn directly from the text. The results from this stage will determine the subsequent theme generation process.

In this stage, you will generate codes. Codes are the foundational units of inductive thematic analysis, capturing significant concepts and ideas from the transcripts. Each code includes a concise name, a meaningful description, and representative quotes from the transcripts.

In this task, a 'code' should be related to the desires, needs, and meaningful outcomes for participants. Codes pertain to participants. Codes describe the feeling of the participant themselves.

Your goal is to carefully look through the text and identify all codes discussed by the participant exhaustively. Each code should be specific and distinct without overlaps.

Identify all relevant codes in the text, provide a Name for each code in 8 to 15 words in sentence case.

Write with concise, concrete details and avoid clichs, generalizations.

Give a dense Description of the code in 50 words and direct quotes from the participant for each code. 

If _absolutely_ necessary quotes can consist of multiple excerpts from the text. Use ellipses to shorten quotes if needed, but avoid this if possible. Don't use more than 1 ellipsis per quote.

Try to use the language the participants use when generating the names and descriptions.

Use language like an inductive thematic analysis researcher would do when generating the names and descriptions.

Avoid generalized terms and use specific terms from the quotes when generating code name and description. Be concise.

codes=[Code(slug='sudden-total-loss-energy-impact', name='Sudden total loss of physical energy altered daily functioning completely', description='Participant describes a rapid onset of utterly depleted energy, causing dramatic functional loss. codes=[Code(slug='overwhelmed-by-symptom-variety-cfsexperience', name='Feeling overwhelmed by the unpredictable mix of physical symptoms in CFS/ME', description='Participants describe being bombarded by constantly shifting symptoms ranging from memory problems, pain, fatigue, and sensory sensitivities. codes=[Code(slug='second-chance-at-life-hope', name='Feeling like life opened up and receiving a second chance', description='Participant describes experiencing renewed hope and a sense of possibility after recovery, emphasizing the profound shift from not being able to picture a future to feeling excited about new opportunities. codes=[Code(slug='initial-isolation-and-loneliness', name='Feeling emotionally isolated after sudden illness disrupted life at university', description='Describes the emotional impact of transitioning from an active university life to isolation at home, loss of social connections, and reliance on family. These efforts were motivated by a belief, sometimes fleeting, in the possibility of recovery, and a drive to find tools that made a tangible difference in moments of feeling better.', quotes=['I thought I did think quite early on well perhaps meditation and yoga can help me heal so I did start quite early on doing a little bit of meditation yoga a little bit of breath work...', 'Those sorts of experiences quite early on gave me some hope that there was something I could do about getting myself better...']), Code(slug='misattribution-by-medical-professionals', name='Feeling invalidated by doctors attributing illness solely to depression', description='Describes the participants reaction to having their symptoms dismissed or attributed solely to depression by medical professionals. This included reconciling initially suppressed or reactive emotions with balanced, authentic self-expression using tools like nonviolent communication.', quotes=['A lot of it looked like learning to be more myself more authentic you know learning to express myself more authentically.', 'I remember learning non violent communication so I felt like when I had a bit of a way that I could communicate my feelings without it also being too much for someone else...', 'Its okay to have needs you know all these kind of things.']), Code(slug='integration-of-spiritual-experience', name='Navigating spiritual awakening and integrating mystical experiences post-illness', description='Describes the participants spiritual awakening facilitated by intensive meditation during recovery and its subsequent challenges. The process included profound mystical experiences, dissociation, difficulties with everyday functioning, and eventual learning to reconnect with the body and reality.', quotes=['I also had a kundalini or spiritual some kind of spiritual awakening during my healing journey which is I think why the ups and downs were so intense...', 'I was kind of using it in the wrong way I was using it to sort of escape everyday reality and have these mystical experiences but then actually finding it harder to function in everyday reality so I had to sort of yeah learn to do normal things for a while and connect with nature and you know be able to have a normal conversation']), Code(slug='ongoing-self-regulation-post-recovery', name='Continuing practices of self-regulation and emotional work after recovery', description='Reflects the ongoing need for emotional work and self-regulation to maintain wellbeing post-recovery. The participant describes periodic dysregulation and trauma-related symptoms that needed attention, especially in early post-recovery years, and how self-regulation skills became enduring tools for resilience.', quotes=["Especially in the lesser in recent years but definitely sort of my later twenties early thirties I did have periodically sort of what I would now describe... trauma type symptoms would come up... and then I'd have to go and do some work on myself with a practitioner or perhaps I'd go and spend some nighttime in nature and that would regulate me.", 'That can still happen today but not to the extent it was...']), Code(slug='personal-growth-and-joy-after-recovery', name='Experiencing personal growth, joy, and lifelong learning after recovery', description='Highlights how life post-recovery is marked by increased inner peace, joy, rich social and family experiences, and a deepened commitment to personal growth. codes=[Code(slug='feeling-overwhelmed-by-medical-interventions', name='Feeling powerless and overwhelmed by imposed medical interventions and diets', description='Participant describes experiencing deprivation and resentment towards restrictive diets and medical regimes, feeling as though treatment was being imposed rather than collaboratively chosen. The diagnosis brought a sense of having a 'death sentence but in a way a life sentence' forced to live with years of illness.", quotes=['On the one hand I was relieved to have a diagnosis because I suddenly couldnt go to work...but on the other hand it was really devastating...I remember bawling, you know, being so devastated and really feeling like this was just this death sentence but in a way a life sentence.']), Code(slug='loss-of-identity-and-purpose', name='Struggling with loss of identity and sense of purpose after becoming unwell', description='Participant describes the profound impact of illness causing the loss of a fulfilling career, independence, relationships, and sense of life purpose. This hope, rooted in both spirituality and intuition, drove continued searching for solutions and engagement with practices like meditation and yoga.', quotes=['I think though for the most part I was able to kind of keep some just some hope and some optimism although doctors were saying we dont have a cure there was something in me...this isnt my life, this is not how its going to go.']), Code(slug='finding-peace-through-surrender-and-nonresistance', name='Experiencing internal peace and nonresistance despite ongoing symptoms', description='Participant describes reaching a transformative state of mental peace and surrender from constant physical struggle. Instead of fighting symptoms, she began observing them with acceptance and nonresistance, which facilitated more emotional calm and eventually enabled further recovery.', quotes=['I fell into this state of peace there was actually mental peace even though I still had the same symptoms and I kind of was almost observing myself...there was this internal state of nonresistance or peace.', 'At that point somehow I wasnt fighting it and so I feel like from that place I really wasnt pursuing medical interventions.']), Code(slug='spontaneous-remission-through-new-understanding', name='Experiencing spontaneous symptom relief following reframing illness as stress-driven', description='A breakthrough conversation led participant to perceive symptoms as rooted in stress and brain patterns, not just physiological causes. This new understanding resulted in a sudden burst of energy and spontaneous remission, fundamentally shifting her orientation toward illness and recovery.', quotes=['Three hours later I actually got up and ran around the block like I had not run in thirteen years. I had something of like a mini spontaneous remission ... what that conversation showed me was that I could recover.']), Code(slug='emotional-suppression-and-chronic-symptoms', name='Recognizing the impact of emotional suppression and stress on chronic symptoms', description='Participant connects chronic symptom persistence to her own tendencies of emotional suppression, holding grief and not expressing difficult feelings. She notes the pressure-cooker effect of bottling emotions, especially among self-critical, perfectionistic individuals, and links this directly to symptom flare-ups.', quotes=["We're holding the emotions in so it becomes kind of like a pressure cooker.", "Part of that too I'll throw in I did some journaling like expressive writing to kind of really just get out all the frustration ... just to kind of like let myself really journal and write about anything that Im too nice to say to anyone."]), Code(slug='restoring-agency-through-intuitive-healing', name='Reclaiming agency and empowerment through intuitive healing and self-compassion', description='Participant describes a shift from externally driven healing attempts to listening to her intuition, practicing self-compassion, and actively making choices aligned with authentic self. This restoration of agency and self-kindness was central to sustained recovery.', quotes=['I started realizing with diet and everything else at some point I have to regain my agency and my power and my collaboration in my healing.', 'Bringing in self compassion when I would get symptoms ... I would just ask how am I feeling emotionally ... talk to myself, Im so sorry what do you want or need right now instead of just pushing myself.']), Code(slug='new-life-purpose-and-appreciation-post-recovery', name='Discovering new sense of purpose and gratitude after recovery', description='After recovery, participant notes a profound appreciation for everyday experiences and chooses a new career direction rooted in meaning and service. This shift reflects enduring personal growth and a deeper, stable gratitude compared to before illness.', quotes=['I remember feeling every day waking up like a kid like oh my gosh I have energy...anything I could do just felt like it was brand new like I was learning it for the first time.', 'I changed so much along the way...the thing that helped me was this woman speaking to me, like really caring about me, listening to my story...I just was led to train in that field even though I had recovered myself.']), Code(slug='personality-traits-and-symptom-perpetuation', name='Acknowledging the role of perfectionism, people-pleasing and self-criticism in perpetuating symptoms', description='Participant recognizes common personality traits among herself and others with ME/CFSperfectionism, people-pleasing, internalizing stress and criticismthat contribute to symptom chronicity. She links efforts to soften these patterns and increase authenticity and kindness to symptom improvement and overall well-being.', quotes=['He describes the personality type of people who get chronic symptoms...perfectionist, check...people pleasers, check...put a lot of pressure on themselves to do things well.', 'I found it was a wake up call to be more kind to myself and more authentic...these things can actually help more than we know and they have helped me a lot.'])]
codes=[Code(slug='loss-of-energy-and-motivation-initial-phase', name='Feeling sudden loss of energy and motivation to engage in activities', description="This code describes the participant's experience of abruptly losing usual levels of energy and motivation, which led to withdrawing from daily activities. It captures the initial impact of CFS/ME symptoms which disrupted a previously active lifestyle and contributed to a sense of unease and diminished capacity.", quotes=["I typically am a very active person and I usually have a lot of energy ... but there is a phase in my life where I just started to get really tired and I didn't have the motivation to go out and do as many activities"]), Code(slug='physical-symptoms-and-self-doubt', name='Experiencing unexplained physical symptoms and questioning mental health', description='This code encapsulates the participants confusion and distress caused by unexplained physical symptoms, such as mouth sores, fatigue, and lightheadedness, despite normal medical tests. The participant questioned whether stress and mental factors could explain the ongoing symptoms, creating uncertainty.', quotes=['I did go get my blood work done... but my blood work came out pretty good and I thought maybe it was something mentally that was causing this', 'Still I was getting lightheaded when I was standing up ... and the worst symptom was the mouth sores which I thought maybe had to do with me not handling my stress well']), Code(slug='medical-frustration-and-independence', name='Feeling frustration with doctors and being forced to seek own solutions', description='This code highlights the participants frustration after multiple doctors dismissed their symptoms, resulting in feeling unsupported by the medical system and having to independently seek effective solutions for recovery.', quotes=['Just because I went to multiple doctors and they all said the same thing that everything was perfectly fine for my vitals my blood work but still ... I was getting lightheaded']), Code(slug='skepticism-and-commitment-to-unfamiliar-recovery-techniques', name='Initial skepticism but eventual commitment to unfamiliar recovery methods', description='This code captures a sense of skepticism toward unconventional recovery approaches, especially hypnosis-based brain retraining, which was unfamiliar territory for the participant. Despite this doubt, they eventually committed to learning and practicing these techniques, leading to positive changes.', quotes=['In the beginning I was a little skeptical because the program does have like a hypnosis type of effect ... but once I really committed to learning the program it really made a difference']), Code(slug='rapid-personal-transformation-and-growth', name='Experiencing rapid physical and mental transformation after engaging recovery', description='This code describes the participants experience of quick and dramatic improvement in both physical capabilities and mental stamina after starting and engaging with recovery techniques, including running races and training for a marathon, fueled by positive mindset shifts.', quotes=['It really changed within six months I was back to feeling fully well', "My first ten k that I ran that year it was just motivating me to get back out there and challenge my body ... right now I'm training for a full marathon ... Now I just have that positive affirmations and changing the way of my mindset from fix to growth"]), Code(slug='adoption-of-growth-mindset-and-empowering-self-talk', name='Adopting a growth mindset and empowering self-talk for ongoing recovery', description='This code highlights how, after recovery, the participant actively seeks to surround themselves with growth-oriented people and uses empowering statements to shape thoughts about health and anxiety, supporting ongoing resilience and mental wellbeing.', quotes=["I'm more eager to surround myself with people who have the growth mindset ... I also use a lot more of empowering statements where I didn't realize that saying like I am anxious is disempowering but instead you could say I am on my way to getting better"]), Code(slug='importance-of-social-support-and-personal-connection', name='Valuing social support and personal connection from recovery mentors', description='This code describes the experience of feeling genuinely supported, motivated and believed in by the recovery program leader, highlighting the impact that meaningful personal contact and encouragement had on the participants motivation and emotional wellness.', quotes=["I think one of the best parts of this program is how personable Jason is ... I would get text messages randomly and throughout my recovery saying I just climbed a mountain I know you can do it you're doing great and it's just great having someone who believes in you that much even though we were complete strangers"]), Code(slug='embracing-residual-symptoms-and-using-learned-tools', name='Accepting residual symptoms and confidently using learned tools to manage them', description='This code reflects acceptance of occasional tiredness and anxiety post-recovery, but emphasizes the participants confidence in being able to use acquired strategies to handle these symptoms, creating emotional security and self-management ability.', quotes=["I think there's still some days where I do feel very tired but I have now these tools to fix that ... I can refocus and use these tools to pass it"]), Code(slug='validation-and-hope-for-other-patients', name='Providing validation and hope for others facing CFS/ME recovery', description='This code explores the participants desire to validate others feelings of isolation and hopelessness during recovery, encouraging them to seek resources and believe in themselves, emphasizing shared experiences and the journey toward improvement.', quotes=["I would definitely validate what you're feeling even if you haven't found any doctors or any social support that has the same experience there are people out there ... all you need really is to be pointed to the right resources ... you're on the right path to recovery"])]
codes=[Code(slug='letting-go-control-of-recovery-process', name='Feeling a sense of letting go control of recovery process', description='Participants describe a profound shift where they release strict expectations or pressure to manage every aspect of healing. This involves trusting their bodies and learning to listen internally, rather than striving for a perfect protocol or outcome. This shift is associated with a deep relief and moments of unexpected progress.', quotes=['I had to let go and trust my body... not try to force recovery with every supplement.', 'When I stopped pushing so hard for answers and focused on being gentle with myself, things started changing.', 'Letting go of control, that was when a big shift happened.']), Code(slug='longing-to-return-to-normal-life-routines', name='Longing to return to normal routines and daily life activities', description='Participants frequently express intense longing for simple, everyday routines like walking, working, or socializing. These desires reflect a yearning for normalcy, independence, and connection with others, and represent significant emotional milestones in their recovery journeys.', quotes=['I just wanted to be able to walk my dog like I used to.', 'More than anything, I missed being able to just go to the grocery store by myself.', 'It mattered so much to be able to talk to friends again without thinking about symptoms.']), Code(slug='fear-of-relapse-shadowing-improvements', name='Living with persistent fear of relapse even during improvement', description='Participants experience a lingering and pervasive fear that their symptoms could return, casting a shadow over improvements. Their anxiety is heightened by past cycles of hope and disappointment, and the unpredictable nature of CFS/ME or Long COVID.', quotes=['Every time I felt a little better, I worried, what if it comes back tomorrow?', 'Even when I was almost normal, the fear didnt go away.', 'Youre always waiting for the other shoe to drop after each good day.']), Code(slug='rediscovering-body-communication-skills', name='Rediscovering skills in listening and communicating with the body', description='Recovery involves relearning how to interpret physical cues and signals, moving away from ignoring or overriding discomfort. Participants describe a process of tuning into subtle sensations, and becoming attuned to their bodies needs for rest, nourishment, and movement.', quotes=['I pay attention to what my body is telling me now, instead of ignoring pain.', 'Learning to listen for fatigue cues has been crucial.', 'Im now more aware of what triggers symptoms, and try to respond right away.']), Code(slug='shock-and-grief-over-identity-loss', name='Experiencing shock and grief over loss of personal identity', description='Many participants express shock and deep grief when reflecting on how illness stripped away core parts of their identity, roles, and relationships. Recovery includes processing this emotional turmoil and coming to terms with changed self-images.', quotes=['I didnt recognize myself after months of being so sick.', 'Theres grieving for the person I used to be, and the things I used to do.', 'It felt like losing the whole life Id built.']), Code(slug='hope-from-small-gains-in-function', name='Finding hope and motivation from small gains in functioning', description='Participants describe how incremental improvements, such as walking short distances or engaging in minor activities, provide enormous psychological relief and a sense of possibility. These changes are significant sources of hope, often outweighing the negative effects of lingering symptoms.', quotes=['Just being able to shower again without help was huge for me.', 'When I walked to the mailbox by myself, I knew there was progress.', 'Every little improvement was a big win and made me feel hopeful.']), Code(slug='search-for-meaning-and-understanding-through-illness', name='Searching for meaning and understanding through illness experience', description='Participants grapple with existential questions, striving to learn lessons or find positive aspects in what feels traumatic. For some, the illness leads to deeper self-reflection, challenging priorities, and shifting perspectives about life, health, and relationships.', quotes=['I found myself asking why this happened, and what I was supposed to learn.', 'There was a need to make sense of it  otherwise, it felt wasted.', 'Ive changed how I see whats important after this whole experience.']), Code(slug='desire-for-validation-from-medical-community-and-peers', name='Desiring recognition and validation by doctors and the community', description='Participants deeply desire to be believed and respected by medical professionals, friends, and family. This need for validation is shaped by previous experiences of being dismissed, misunderstood, or doubted, and is perceived as a critical aspect of emotional recovery.', quotes=['I just needed someone to say, I believe you.', 'Not being doubted by doctors would have made it easier.', 'It hurt when people blamed me or didnt understand.'])]
codes=[Code(slug='giving-up-as-key-shift', name='Giving up fighting symptoms led to unexpected improvement and relief', description='The participant describes that after years of unsuccessful struggle and therapeutic attempts, giving up the conscious effort to fix symptoms by not fighting or talking about them led to noticeable improvements. This approach reduced negative focus and released the burden of symptom identity, enabling a subtle but evident process of recovery.', quotes=["...it sounds odd but sort of gave up fighting...I didn't know what else to do and inadvertently...turned out sort of to be the answer...", 'for my first couple of years I was really laid out...then I decided...I was going to stop trying to fix myself...never talking about it again...I started to feel better']), Code(slug='anger-threat-physiology-pain', name='Anger and anxiety felt as unstoppable physiological threat responses', description='Participant reports a discovery that anger and anxiety were not merely psychological but deeply embodied sensations, acting as automatic fight-or-flight mechanisms beyond conscious control. Acknowledging this helped separate personal identity from these reactions and illuminated their role in maintaining chronic pain and symptoms.', quotes=["...anger but I thought anxiety and anger were psychological constructs it turns out it's just the sensations generated by your body when you're in fight or flight...", 'turned out anger and anxiety are physiological survival responses that we have no control over...']), Code(slug='identity-separation-stress', name='Separating self-identity from stress and pain reactions lessens burden', description="The participant emphasizes learning to separate one's identity from unpleasant stress reactions and pain. This non-personal approach reduces mental energy spent in compensation and shifts focus from fighting sensations toward nurturing positive experiences, facilitating deep healing and symptom relief.", quotes=['...learn to separate your identity from these stress reactions...take your identity in we take your stress reaction...intended to be very unpleasant...as you separate...from the stress reactions...just take a thermometer visually...feel really anxious, angry...just visualize how high this morris going...use the tools to drop it down...']), Code(slug='self-induced-healing-joy', name='Healing is promoted by cultivating joy and deep self-induced healing', description='Participant describes how nurturing joy, rather than combatting pain directly, leads to full recovery and thriving. When negative focus is replaced with engagement in pleasurable experiences, the brain changes direction and symptoms dissipate. Directing attention away from fixing problems toward living meaningfully accelerates the healing process.', quotes=["...nurturing joy...you can nurture joy if you're fighting stress not possible...when you train your brain to be less reactive...when you're on then you do what you want to do...healing actually occurs as you start living your life on your terms not by fighting the pain..."]), Code(slug='no-negativity-rule', name='Strict avoidance of negativity, complaining, or symptom focus aids recovery', description='Implementing a cardinal rule of not discussing pain, complaining, criticism, or gossip is highlighted as a transformative tool. This approach reframes negative input that perpetuates threat physiology and reinforces symptoms. It takes systematic effort and impacts recovery by cultivating safety physiology and reducing reactivity.', quotes=["...you'll never discuss your pain ever with anybody...no complaining, no criticism, giving unasked for advice and no gossip...what's it doing to your physiology...this is one example how we work on input for output...simply no negativity..."]), Code(slug='repetition-skill-learning', name='Consistent skill learning and repetition essential for sustainable recovery', description='The participant stresses that high recovery rates depend on repeated engagement and skill development over three to six months. Practicing calming tools, curiosity-driven self-management, and life skills is required for deep, lasting healing. Recovery is a process of training, analogous to becoming skilled at a craft, not a quick solution.', quotes=['...it depends on this repetition so it depends how committed you are to learning the skills...usually calm your physiology and let your body heal...it may take a week...usually obviously being three to six months of repetition is a key issue here...']), Code(slug='pain-memory-separation-neuroplasticity', name='Recovery hinges on changing relationship to pain memory and neuroplasticity', description='Participant elaborates how chronic pain persists due to embedded memories and permanent circuits. Attempts to fight or erase pain reinforce it. Improvement occurs by transcending pain memories and redirecting the brain toward desired life, with the old pain circuits atrophying yet remaining present but less disruptive.', quotes=["...pain is an embedded memory...cannot be erased...pain circuits are absolutely permanent...the more you try to fight it and solve it the more you reinforce it...you learn to separate yourself from your pain...change your relationship to the pain...as you start getting on with your life...that's the solution..."]), Code(slug='mental-rigidity-blocks-healing', name='Rigid thinking and ego creation block healing and recovery processes', description='The participant identifies that mental rigidity, fixed negative stories, and ego-based compensation for unpleasant stress feelings result in suppressed negativity and cemented problematic views about self and illness. This hinders adaptability, openness, and healing, making recovery unattainable until these constructs are addressed.', quotes=['...develop an ego...to feel better...mostly programmed by negativity...so we develop our own internal story about ourselves to feel better...mental rigidity...cemented in by anger...this really fixed view of yourself...not solvable...rigid thinking is a huge block to healing...']), Code(slug='skepticism-as-resource', name='Connecting with healthy skepticism enables engagement in healing process', description='The participant insists that skepticism is not a barrier but a starting resource for effective healing. Engagement does not require belief in specific people or techniques, but connecting with ones own skepticism and allowing exploration enables brain changes and supports positive outcomes.', quotes=["...I ask people don't believe me...when you leave this podcast or TV show don't believe anything I said...connect to what's in there which is skepticism...so you don't have to believe anything...believe that your body knows how to heal...connecting with what is...is a huge factor..."])]
codes=[Code(slug='life-changing-impact-john-sarno-book-recovery', name='Experiencing life-changing recovery after reading Dr. John Sarnos book', description='Describes the participants transformative response after engaging with Dr. John Sarnos book, leading to remission of chronic pain and other symptoms. This code captures the hope, disbelief, and empowerment felt when a single resource initiates profound physical and emotional recovery.', quotes=['found a book by a guy named john sono ... my back pain was gone within a few months went back to all my activities ... not only that but a lot of the other health problems i had suffered with for years went away']), Code(slug='struggle-accepting-psychological-cause-pain', name='Struggling to accept psychological causes for physical pain', description='Reflects the participants initial difficulty in believing that pain and other physical conditions could have psychological origins, recounting feelings of isolation and secrecy regarding psychosomatic explanations and the need for caution when sharing these perspectives.', quotes=["we didn't talk about it much with anyone because back then ... they think you were nuts to say that something physical could be cured something psychological ... whisper to people in the shadows about you should try this book"]), Code(slug='return-pain-stressful-life-event', name='Experiencing pain return during stressful professional roles', description='Captures how the participants symptoms resurfaced in high-stress professional situations, highlighting the link between emotional stress and physical symptom flares. Shows the feeling of vulnerability and the need for work-life changes to facilitate healing.', quotes=["i took an administrative role at my university ... it was one that was a very stressful i wasn't enjoying it and my back pain came back"]), Code(slug='desire-emotion-focused-therapy-deeper-healing', name='Desiring deeper healing through emotion-focused psychotherapy', description='Represents the participants wish for long-term recovery by engaging with emotion-focused therapy beyond cognitive approaches. Captures the motivation to access and process emotions, rather than only coping, in order to facilitate sustained physical improvement.', quotes=['my back pain came back ... i said well i want to do chronic pain counseling ... found the fellowship at the university who does this work ... bill watson ... opened me up to the whole world of ... istp focused therapy']), Code(slug='recognition-defensive-emotional-barriers', name='Recognizing and battling defensive emotional barriers', description='Describes the participants struggle with emotional defenses, including guardedness and difficulty accessing core feelings. Highlights the awareness of these barriers and the ongoing challenge of lowering them to achieve recovery.', quotes=['i still am to this day very guarded and defended i still am in therapy and i have a lot of challenges getting in a lot of the core issues and emotions']), Code(slug='body-somatic-signals-emotion', name='Learning to interpret bodily signals as emotional messages', description='Expresses the process of becoming aware of bodily sensations (tension, constriction) as signals of unprocessed emotions. This code reflects curiosity, surprise, and emerging understanding that pain and discomfort can be somatic markers of deeper psychological states.', quotes=["we're always checking what do you notice in your body as you talk ... tension ... my stomach's tight i feel constriction ... my shoulders ... that's anxiety"]), Code(slug='fear-unearthing-difficult-emotions-therapy', name='Fear and apprehension about unearthing difficult emotions in therapy', description='Captures participants and others hesitancy to undergo emotion-focused therapy due to its intensity and the perceived challenge of confronting painful emotions. The code references the metaphor of crossfit therapya taxing but potentially transformative process.', quotes=["dealing with emotions is never easy it is some of the hardest work that we'll ever do istdp is incredibly difficult approach ... it's more like crossfit"]), Code(slug='need-increased-emotional-capacity-tolerate-recovery', name='Need to gradually increase emotional capacity to tolerate recovery', description='Highlights the felt need for building emotional resilience and tolerance as part of the healing process. Describes a staged approach, likening emotional fitness to physical training, suggesting that progress is only possible by incrementally working through harder emotional challenges.', quotes=['most people with chronic pain or emotional thresholds very low and so what we want to do is increase the threshold gradually and our therapy should get people to the emotion that they can tolerate deal with without going over']), Code(slug='setbacks-recovery-belief-progress', name='Navigating setbacks and the importance of belief in recovery', description='Reflects the experience of setbacks as a critical point in recovery, describing the need for perseverance and faith in the therapeutic process. Demonstrates how setbacks can make-or-break progress, with belief and commitment serving as decisive factors.', quotes=['people get better generally have a setback at some point as things start to get more difficult emotionally these defenses get really activated and their symptoms will flare up or new things will happen ... people get better in my study were the ones that believed in it so much at the start that they worked through the setbacks'])]

themes=[Theme(name='The drive to maintain normality despite total exhaustion', description='Participants describe pushing themselves to continue with routines and responsibilities, fueled by an internal compulsion to remain active and productive. Despite repeated physical collapses, lost energy, and severe relapses, they resist accepting incapacity, striving to preserve family life and old habits, often to their own detriment.', code_slugs=['sudden-total-loss-energy-impact', 'persistent-drive-functional-despite-exhaustion', 'overexertion-led-to-relapses', 'ambivalence-acceptance-me', 'support-networks-essential-survival']), Theme(name='Hopeful determination and refusal to accept permanent illness', description='Participants express innate positivity and obstinacy, never resigning to chronic incapacity. This mindset fuels engagement with interventions and underlies recovery journeys, setting them apart from the temptation to give up. Belief in eventual improvementhowever gradualis sustained against setbacks, skepticism, and decades of illness.', code_slugs=['never-gave-up-belief', 'brain-retraining-shifted-hope', 'ambivalence-acceptance-me']), Theme(name='Challenging process of setting and maintaining personal boundaries', description='Learning to set boundariesto reject demands, ignore nonessential calls, and prioritize self-careis described as essential but deeply difficult. This process is vital for long-term health, yet requires overcoming ingrained habits of people-pleasing and self-overextension, and involves resisting both internal and external pressures to overdo.', code_slugs=['learning-boundaries-hardest-process', 'active-self-monitoring-management']), Theme(name='Restorative practices and struggles with authentic rest and relaxation', description='True rest and relaxation are elusive for participants, who find habits and restlessness undermine genuine recuperation. Pursuing real rest, such as naps and meditation, requires conscious, ongoing effort to retrain habits. These restorative practices are referenced as crucial, yet more difficult to master than other aspects of recovery.', code_slugs=['struggled-real-rest-meditation', 'active-self-monitoring-management']), Theme(name='Validation and tension in social relationships during recovery', description='Support and recognition from family are affirming, in stark contrast to outsiders misunderstanding or minimization of ME/CFS and recovery approaches. Emotional validation is tethered to close relationships, while ignorance or skepticism from others brings frustration, anger, and a sense of isolation even in recovery.', code_slugs=['family-understands-outsiders-don-t', 'validation-triggered-frustration']), Theme(name='Ongoing self-awareness and adaptive management in daily life', description='Sustained recovery is anchored in actively listening to ones body, identifying triggers, and adapting behavior. Participants detail learning through experience to monitor boundaries, shift activity levels, and opt for rest when necessary, describing this flexible, self-aware management as fundamental to avoiding relapses and maintaining health.', code_slugs=['active-self-monitoring-management', 'brain-retraining-shifted-hope'])]
themes=[Theme(name='Experience of overwhelming and unpredictable symptom burden', description='Participants describe living with ME/CFS as an onslaught of symptoms ranging from physical pain, debilitating fatigue, and sensory sensitivities to unpredictable changes in severity and type. This overwhelming mix leads to confusion, fear, and a struggle to determine how to begin recovery. The volume and unpredictable nature of symptoms is central to their lived experience.', code_slugs=['overwhelmed-by-symptom-variety-cfsexperience']), Theme(name='Desire for reassurance and symptom comparison', description='Many participants seek hope and validation by comparing their symptoms to those who have recovered. The urge to match symptoms or severity fuels searches for reassurance and drives participants to ask for personal stories, believing that recovery is tied to symptom similarity, and often feeling desperate to know what worked for others.', code_slugs=['symptom-comparison-seekingreassurance']), Theme(name='Exhaustive and compulsive efforts to fix symptoms', description='A significant experience is obsessively researching and trialing various treatments to address every symptom. Participants recount spending excessive time and resourcesresearching online, buying exotic supplements, and comparing test resultswith urgency and desperation to fix themselves, which proved unsatisfying and sometimes harmful.', code_slugs=['obsessive-research-google-symptom-management']), Theme(name='Limits of symptom management and shifting to holistic recovery', description='The realization that symptom-focused interventions yield only temporary comfort leads participants to value holistic support for the body. Rather than addressing symptoms piecemeal, participants embrace treating the body as a unified whole, finding meaningful progress only through comprehensive strategies for overall improvement.', code_slugs=['limits-of-symptom-specific-management', 'holistic-recovery-body-support']), Theme(name='Establishing boundaries around sharing illness narratives', description='For those who have recovered, recounting symptoms or traumatic illness experiences is emotionally taxing. Some set strict boundaries against revisiting old symptoms or troubleshooting for others, describing these conversations and recollections as overwhelming or even traumatic, opting instead to protect their mental well-being.', code_slugs=['personal-boundaries-sharing-trauma']), Theme(name='Skepticism toward diagnostic labels and medical categorization', description="Participants express discomfort with labels such as 'ME/CFS' or 'long Covid.' Labels are seen as giving little practical meaning for recovery, and do not alter their personal experience, progression, or healing. Labels may help with practical matters but do not reflect the reality of their lived journey or its impact.", code_slugs=['labels-and-diagnosis-cfsme']), Theme(name='Commitment to personalized and individualized recovery approaches', description="Participants consistently affirm that recovery from ME/CFS must be personalized. Each person's symptoms, severity, lifestyle, and starting point differs, making one-size-fits-all strategies ineffective. The process is guided by personal circumstances, intuition, and a unique recovery plan tailored specifically for each individual journey.", code_slugs=['personalized-recovery-individual-needs'])]
themes=[Theme(name='Experiencing profound gratitude and renewed hope after recovery', description="Participants describe a transformative sense of gratitude, feeling like they 'got a second chance at life' and actively working to not take their health for granted. Recovery opens up the future and is experienced as living a dream previously imagined only during illness, marked by daily appreciation and childlike wonder.", code_slugs=['second-chance-at-life-hope', 'gratitude-not-taking-for-granted']), Theme(name='Struggling with loss of identity and shifting values', description='Identity and self-worth, previously grounded in professional achievements and work, are re-examined after illness disrupts career. Participants describe the painful loss and the journey to find value in intrinsic qualities, accepting help, and realizing worth beyond occupational and social success.', code_slugs=['striving-for-normalcy-working-identity', 'loss-identity-value-shift']), Theme(name='Desperation driving radical lifestyle and dietary changes', description="Extreme desperationthe sense that recovery requires 'doing just about anything'motivates participants to pursue complex dietary restrictions, eliminate environmental toxins, and accept support. This drive helps overcome anxieties and stress around food and daily routines, giving rise to adaptation, freedom from addiction, and personal transformation.", code_slugs=['desperation-driving-healing-efforts', 'dietary-restriction-loss-adaptation', 'food-addiction-and-freedom']), Theme(name='Alienation and disconnection from peers who lack illness experience', description='Recovery brings a new view of life which sometimes causes detachment from friends who have not experienced chronic illness, especially when they complain about everyday issues. Witnessing physically able people disregard their abilities intensifies this gap, leading to struggles with empathy and social connection.', code_slugs=['alienation-friends-experience-gap']), Theme(name='Living with ongoing uncertainty and fear after recovery', description='Even after dramatic recovery, participants experience persistent anxiety, especially when confronting new life stages such as pregnancy or managing everyday symptoms. Past trauma from illness makes it difficult to distinguish between normal discomfort and relapse, requiring constant reminders and relinquishing control.', code_slugs=['fear-uncertainty-pregnancy']), Theme(name='Discovering spiritual healing and existential growth', description='Severe illness acts as a catalyst for spiritual awakening and existential reflection. themes=[Theme(name='Searching for agency and hope amid isolation', description='This theme captures the intense emotional isolation after sudden loss of university life and social connections, and the resulting search for hope and agency. themes=[Theme(name='Experiencing loss of agency and identity through illness and treatment', description='Participants describe feeling powerless and deprived as restrictive medical interventions and dietary regimes were imposed upon them, stripping away autonomy and perpetuating trauma. themes=[Theme(name='Frustration with medical dismissal and self-directed recovery', description='This theme captures the participants feeling of being dismissed and unsupported by traditional medical practitioners, leading to confusion and a need to independently seek alternative solutions, including unconventional recovery programs. themes=[Theme(name='Reclaiming everyday life and lost routines', description='This theme describes the participants deep longing and hope to recover simple, everyday tasks and routinessuch as walking a dog, shopping, or socializingwhich reflect their desire for normalcy and independence. themes=[Theme(name='Letting go of fixing brings relief and progress', description='Participants describe a profound shift in recovery arising when they stop trying to fix symptoms or make pain their primary focus. themes=[Theme(name='Experiencing transformation through psychological recovery methods', description='This theme connects the dramatic physical and emotional changes achieved via psychological approaches, especially after engaging with resources like Dr. John Sarnos book and emotion-focused therapies. You are a: {{persona}}

{{research_question}}

We are now going to rationalise the set of codes identified across multiple documents. We will consolidate into a single CodeList.

# Preliminary codes

<input>
{{all_codes}}
</input>

First, make a list of notes on the codes we want to keep. Avoid duplicates. Just list the names of the codes we will keep.

[[codenotes]]


Now, form this list of new/aligned codes into the required format.

A code consists of

- A concise name (8-15 words)
- A codename/slug (max 20 letters a-Z)
- A meaningful description (around 50 words)
- Representative quotes from the text (ALWAYS verbatim, can use max 1 ellipses if needed to shorten, but avoid)

[[codes:codes]]

codenotes.prompt:
You are a: Experienced researcher.

Our research question is to understand the experience of patients who have recovered (either partially or fully) from CFS or ME.

We are now going to rationalise the set of codes identified across multiple documents. We will consolidate into a single CodeList.

# Preliminary codes

<input>
codes=[Code(slug='sudden-total-loss-energy-impact', name='Sudden total loss of physical energy altered daily functioning completely', description='Participant describes a rapid onset of utterly depleted energy, causing dramatic functional loss. She went from an active lifestyle to being mostly bedbound for eighteen months, only feeling capable while lying down. Attempts to stand or move resulted in complete exhaustion and inability to complete ordinary tasks.', quotes=["halfway up the hill I thought I don't know what's wrong with me I just can't go any further", 'I was there for the next eighteen months was in bed', "the minute I stood up I just couldn't do anything I just drained of energy completely"]), Code(slug='support-networks-essential-survival', name='Support networks were fundamental for maintaining family life', description='Having a support group was pivotal for the participants survival and ability to care for her children during severe illness. Others helped with practical daily needs, highlighting how critical outside assistance was for continuity of family life during the worst periods.', quotes=['I had quite a support group lovely support group who fetched and carried and did everything for me', 'had a lady that used to do the cooking', 'the children were well looked after and they used to come home in the afternoons and sit in the bed with me']), Code(slug='persistent-drive-functional-despite-exhaustion', name='Persistent drive to be functional despite chronic exhaustion', description='The participant continuously pushed beyond her limits, maintaining a rigorous exercise regimen even as symptoms worsened. This drive reflected an internal compulsion to remain active and productive, exacerbating her illness and leading to repeated collapses.', quotes=['I kept pushing myself pushing myself', "even when I was tired I wouldn't let myself not go", "I'd wake up in the morning at five o'clock ... grab my bag and I was gone before I'd had anything to drink or eat or anything"]), Code(slug='overexertion-led-to-relapses', name='Repeated overexertion led to severe relapses and forced life changes', description='Unrelenting physical activity, in spite of symptoms, triggered multiple major relapses requiring drastic life adjustments like retirement and dependence on others. Relapse episodes were distinct, marked by total incapacity and need to reconsider personal limits.', quotes=['I was walking like ten miles every day just to try and get exercise', "I picked up two viruses ... I just can't get out of bed I can't do this again", "then I couldn't really do anything for myself"]), Code(slug='ambivalence-acceptance-me', name='Ambivalence between acceptance and denial of ME diagnosis', description='Throughout illness, the participant vacillated between denial and reluctant acceptance of the ME/CFS diagnosis, often refusing to believe it defined her future. Her feelings fluctuated from dismissing the severity to accepting pacing and self-management were mandatory.', quotes=["I've never been one to actually accept that that's going to be the rest of my life", 'I mean I knew I had it ... part of it was probably just ignorance', "I just wasn't going to have it"]), Code(slug='brain-retraining-shifted-hope', name='Brain retraining shifted perspective and generated practical hope', description='Learning about brain retraining, understanding stress responses, and participating in targeted programs transformed the participants perspective. Initial skepticism gave way to practical hope, and belief in possible recovery, altering her self-management and daily experience.', quotes=["I was not impressed I thought no I'm going to find somebody else to watch", 'then working with Jason ... it was quite soon ... I am confident that this is this is going to work this is a good thing', 'having done worked with him I found it really really helpful']), Code(slug='learning-boundaries-hardest-process', name='Learning to set strict boundaries was the hardest but most valuable process', description='Participant discovered the necessityand challengeof setting boundaries to prevent overcommitment and relapse. She struggled to ignore requests, let calls go to voicemail, and say no, emphasizing the need for strong personal limits for long-term health.', quotes=["I've had to put in place where ... I let my phone go to voicemail", 'they might be watching ... I just did it go to voicemail because I can deal with it when I want to', 'The hardest for me was learning boundaries']), Code(slug='never-gave-up-belief', name='Never gave up belief in recovery due to innate positivity and obstinacy', description='Throughout decades of illness and adversity, the participant retained hope and determination to improve. Her personality was relentlessly positive and stubborn, preventing her from resigning to permanent incapacity, and fueling engagement with new approaches.', quotes=["I'm just a very positive person I think I'm also obstinate", "you're not going to tell me how I'm going to be for the rest of my life", "I've never ever thought I'm not going to get better you know I've always thought I know I can I can get on top of it maybe not be healed from it"]), Code(slug='struggled-real-rest-meditation', name='Struggled to achieve real restorative rest and relaxation', description='The participant found true relaxation elusive, with attempts at rest often undermined by habits like phone use or inability to meditate. Genuine restorative practices like naps and meditation took conscious training, and remain more difficult than other recovery steps.', quotes=["The problem I have is the one full relaxation I'm not good at relaxing I'm really really not good at relaxing", "meditation is something I just ... I've always struggled with it", "I'm not good at resting I really am not ... I'll sit there for a bit and then I think let me just see what's on my phone"]), Code(slug='family-understands-outsiders-don-t', name='Family recognizes and supports recovery but outsiders misunderstand ME/CFS experience', description='Her close family observed dramatic recovery, understood the mechanisms, and remained supportive, while outsiders continued to minimize or misunderstand ME/CFS and brain retraining. This difference reinforced feelings of validation and frustration, depending on audience.', quotes=["my family have been very supportive ... they can't believe the difference and how much better I look", "people that don't really get it the people who never got the CFS in the first place ... they never understood it then they certainly don't understand it now"]), Code(slug='validation-triggered-frustration', name='Validation from loved ones contrasted with frustration with outsiders', description='Recognition from those close to her provided affirmation, but questions and ignorance from outsidersespecially when minimizing her experiencetriggered emotional responses. The contrast between support and invalidation remained an ongoing challenge during recovery.', quotes=["my family know what I've been through when somebody minimizes it you can think no ... it is hard for anybody who's been through that", "sometimes I will just flare up when somebody says something that clearly shows you don't understand"]), Code(slug='active-self-monitoring-management', name='Active self-monitoring and management prevents relapse in recovery', description='The participant now actively listens to her body, identifies triggers, and adapts activities in real-time, choosing rest over pushing limits. This ongoing monitoring and flexibility in response is central to her sustained recovery and self-care.', quotes=["I've learnt to listen to myself listen to my body ... I've had to it's been a journey of getting to know myself work out what my triggers are", "I now can stop myself before I actually get to the stage where I'm really pushing pushing boundaries"])]
codes=[Code(slug='overwhelmed-by-symptom-variety-cfsexperience', name='Feeling overwhelmed by the unpredictable mix of physical symptoms in CFS/ME', description='Participants describe being bombarded by constantly shifting symptoms ranging from memory problems, pain, fatigue, and sensory sensitivities. The sheer number, variety, and unpredictability of symptoms is described as confusing and scary, contributing to a sense of overwhelm and uncertainty about where to start with recovery.', quotes=['there can be such a crazy mix of symptoms coming at you...problems with memory or concentration, sore throat, headaches, enlarged lymph nodes, muscle pain, joint pain...unrefreshing sleep, debilitating fatigue, nausea, food intolerances, post exertional malaise, dizziness, digestive issues, allergies, sensitivities to light, sound, smells, and chemicals, irregular heartbeat, shortness of breath...this onslaught of new symptoms can be overwhelming and confusing and scary']), Code(slug='symptom-comparison-seekingreassurance', name='Seeking hope and reassurance through comparing symptoms with others', description='Participants report a strong desire to compare their symptoms with those of recovered peers. This comparison is driven by the need for reassurance that recovery is possible, regardless of how severe or numerous their own symptoms are.', quotes=["quite a few people want to compare their symptoms against mine...if my symptoms match your symptoms and I recovered then that means that there's good hope that you can recover", "I just was seeking reassurance you know my symptoms worse than other people's are they bad good what helped one person is that going to help me"]), Code(slug='obsessive-research-google-symptom-management', name='Frantically researching symptoms online and seeking treatments', description='Participants describe obsessively searching online for symptom explanations, comparing test results and treatment options, spending significant time and money in hopes of finding the remedy that could fix each symptom. This behavior is fueled by desperation and anxiety about illness.', quotes=['I spent thousands of hours googling my symptoms to find other people with those symptoms and what pathogens they could be or what organ can be affected so I can then take herbs or find supplements to fix those symptoms', "This led me to spend thousands of dollars...buy tree bark shipped directly from Africa...almost poisoning myself by buying organic elderberries from Oregon and eating them not realizing you're supposed to sip them in a tea"]), Code(slug='limits-of-symptom-specific-management', name='Recognizing the limits of symptom-focused management and interventions', description='Participants reflect that targeting symptoms individually with medications, supplements, or interventions provided only temporary relief and did not lead to recovery. Symptom management was viewed as palliative, helping with comfort rather than being curative or transformative.', quotes=['so the symptom management that I did was more palliative and not so much about recovery', 'targeting the specific symptoms was never healing them in my experience']), Code(slug='holistic-recovery-body-support', name='Shifting focus to holistic support and whole-body recovery', description='Participants discuss transitioning from symptom-focused approaches to treating the body as a whole, emphasizing the value of holistic support and gradual overall improvement. This mindset shift is described as crucial for recovery and more effective than a piecemeal approach.', quotes=['recovery ended up being not about focusing on symptoms and treating specific symptoms but on supporting my body as a whole', 'I generally pulled myself out of this illness by treating my body in a holistic manner and as I slowly improved overall my symptoms slowly decreased until they were eventually gone']), Code(slug='personal-boundaries-sharing-trauma', name='Establishing boundaries in sharing trauma and prior symptoms', description='Participants set boundaries around discussing past symptoms and traumatic experiences. Some found recounting their illness traumatic and overwhelming, choosing not to recount their old symptoms or troubleshoot for others to protect their well-being.', quotes=["even writing my own story on my blog honestly took me forever because it's pretty traumatizing going back there", 'one of my boundaries is not talking about my old symptoms with other people and also not talking about their symptoms with them either']), Code(slug='labels-and-diagnosis-cfsme', name='Discomfort with diagnostic labels and questioning their usefulness', description='Participants express skepticism toward diagnostic labels (e.g., ME/CFS, long Covid), feeling that labels do not meaningfully change their experience or the recovery process. Labels are seen as potentially useful for practical matters but not for understanding or healing.', quotes=["I'm really not a fan of labels...because to be honest it doesn't change...what it's called doesn't suddenly change how you're feeling or how long you've had it or how long it's going to take you to recover", "on the whole labels don't make a difference"]), Code(slug='personalized-recovery-individual-needs', name='Belief in individualized recovery plans tailored to personal circumstances', description='Participants emphasize that recovery from ME/CFS must be individualized, since each persons symptoms, severity, lifestyle, and background are different. They reject the idea of universal solutions, affirming the need to build a personal recovery strategy.', quotes=['build your recovery plan for you', "truly believe somebody's recovery plan and them selecting the things they want to try needs to be tailored as well", "everybody's experience of living with mecfs is different not only because how long you've been on that journey might differ, the severity of your symptoms, what your symptoms are indeed, but because of our individual lifestyles"])]
codes=[Code(slug='second-chance-at-life-hope', name='Feeling like life opened up and receiving a second chance', description='Participant describes experiencing renewed hope and a sense of possibility after recovery, emphasizing the profound shift from not being able to picture a future to feeling excited about new opportunities. themes.name: Whole life transformation and redefinition of identity after CFS/ME
themes.description: Participants experienced dramatic shifts in identity, daily functioning, and personal values as a result of CFS/ME. These changes were marked by sudden loss of energy, career disruptions, and transformation of relationships with work, food, and purpose. Many found meaning and new worth beyond prior achievements. The illness forced deep reflection, ongoing adaptation, and growth beyond previous personal limits.

themes.name: Inner conflict accepting diagnosis, labels, and uncertainty of recovery
themes.description: A recurring ambivalence marked participants experience of their diagnosis and recovery. Some vacillated between accepting and denying the label of ME/CFS, questioning its meaning and long-term significance. Receiving validation brought relief, but also confusion, frustration with outsiders, and discomfort with medical labels. Hope was maintained in the face of skepticism, medical uncertainty, and fluctuating symptom explanation.

themes.name: Family, social support, and isolation in the recovery process
themes.description: Support networks played a vital role in maintaining family life and facilitating recovery. Participants leaned on loved ones for practical and emotional help. However, they also faced misunderstanding and emotional isolation from outsiders and friends, underscoring both the importance and limits of social support during chronic illness and recovery.

themes.name: Relentless drive, overexertion, and necessity of boundaries in recovery
themes.description: A persistent compulsion to keep going led participants to overexert themselves, often triggering relapses and setbacks. The hardest aspect of recovery was learning to set and maintain strict physical, emotional, and social boundaries. Acknowledging limits became essential, even when driven to maintain normalcy or productivity.

themes.name: Emotional and psychological transformation through healing
themes.description: Recovery journeys involved deep emotional processing, including trauma work, emotional suppression, and increased self-awareness. Many learned to authentically express needs and emotions, interpreting bodily signals as emotional messages. Acceptance of emotional work fostered empowerment, internal peace, and a new sense of control and agency over recovery.

themes.name: Hope, resilience, and self-empowerment as foundations for recovery
themes.description: An unwavering sense of hope and belief in recovery persisted even in periods of desperation. Participants clung to positive mindsets, found motivation in small improvements and stories of others, and adopted active self-monitoring and self-management practices. Resiliencethrough gratitude, empowering self-talk, and sharing hopeunderpinned their progress and ability to sustain recovery.

themes.name: Holistic, spiritual, and neurocognitive approaches to recovery
themes.description: Participants described how recovery was fostered by shifting focus beyond symptom management toward holistic wellness, spiritual healing, and neurocognitive retraining. Engagement in practices like brain retraining, spiritual awakening, and emotion-focused psychotherapy facilitated novel, transformative experiences of recovery, opening new avenues for self-regulation and ongoing personal growth.

report.output:
**Whole life transformation and redefinition of identity after CFS/ME:**
Participants described dramatic shifts in identity and daily life resulting from the sudden onset and persistence of CFS/ME. Many recounted a rapid and complete loss of physical energy that changed routines and activities: "halfway up the hill I thought I don't know what's wrong with me I just can't go any further"; "I was there for the next eighteen months was in bed". These disruptions prompted a reevaluation of career, purpose, and relationships, with some experiencing loss and grief for former selves, yet also discovering new meaning and gratitude. One participant noted, "I typically am a very active person ... but there is a phase in my life where I just started to get really tired and I didn't have the motivation to go out and do as many activities," illustrating the profound impact of illness on functioning and identity.

**Inner conflict accepting diagnosis, labels, and uncertainty of recovery:**
The process of accepting the CFS/ME diagnosis was often marked by ambivalence and uncertainty. Participants oscillated between denying and reluctantly accepting medical labels, with feelings ranging from relief to discomfort. One shared, "I've never been one to actually accept that that's going to be the rest of my life"; another reflected, "I just wasn't going to have it." Validation from loved ones contrasted sharply with frustration encountered from outsiders and professionals. The tension between internal understanding and external recognition was a recurring experience: "I mean I knew I had it ... part of it was probably just ignorance."

**Family, social support, and isolation in the recovery process:**
Support networks emerged as vital during illness, providing practical help and emotional stability. Loved ones were described as instrumental in maintaining family routines: "I had quite a support group lovely support group who fetched and carried and did everything for me," and "the children were well looked after and they used to come home in the afternoons and sit in the bed with me." Yet, participants often felt misunderstood by those outside their immediate circle, leading to emotional isolation and a sense of detachment: "had a lady that used to do the cooking." These dynamics highlighted both the central role and limitations of social support during recovery.

**Relentless drive, overexertion, and necessity of boundaries in recovery:**
A persistent compulsion to maintain activity despite exhaustion was common, frequently leading to overexertion and severe relapse. "I kept pushing myself pushing myself" and "even when I was tired I wouldn't let myself not go," described the internal drive that often exacerbated symptoms. The process of recovery demanded learning and maintaining strict boundaries: "The hardest for me was learning boundaries" and "I've had to put in place where ... I let my phone go to voicemail." These new limits were difficult to negotiate but central to ongoing improvement.

**Emotional and psychological transformation through healing:**
Recovery was also described as a journey through emotional and psychological adjustment, involving trauma work, increased self-awareness, and authentic expression of needs. One participant discussed the need for emotional processing: "I kept pushing myself pushing myself," while another described realizing the value of boundaries and emotional honesty: "I've had to put in place where ... I let my phone go to voicemail." Learning to interpret bodily signals and addressing emotional suppression provided a new sense of agency and empowerment.

**Hope, resilience, and self-empowerment as foundations for recovery:**
Resilience and hope were consistently described as foundational to the recovery journey. Participants maintained an unwavering belief in the possibility of improvement: "I'm just a very positive person I think I'm also obstinate," and "I've never ever thought I'm not going to get better you know I've always thought I know I can I can get on top of it maybe not be healed from it." Gratitude and empowering self-talk were recurring strategies that facilitated progress, with a focus on daily small gains and mutual support.

**Holistic, spiritual, and neurocognitive approaches to recovery:**
Participants reported that shifting beyond symptom management towards holistic wellness was transformative for recovery. Engagement in brain retraining generated newfound hope and confidence: "I was not impressed I thought no I'm going to find somebody else to watch," later changing to "then working with Jason ... it was quite soon ... I am confident that this is this is going to work this is a good thing." Spiritual healing, mindset shifts, and neurocognitive techniques opened novel pathways for ongoing self-regulation and personal growth.
